title: @Riot: Skeletons, yay or nay?
body:
There are two actual skeleton skins, being Jurassic Kog'maw and Cho'Gath, and the splash art for Grim Reaper Karthus has him as a skeleton.

Is the fact that bones are "taboo" is some countries, one big one specifically, a deterrent for making more skeletal themed champions and/or skins?

replies.body: Human skeletons and guts are not allowed, basically. I believe it's less of an issue with skins, as those can just be disabled entirely without causing gameplay to be different from region to region.

This. 

Human skeletons are a no-go, but animal-like or demon skeletons are okay, like some of Gravelord Azir's motifs
On a side note: What prompted the decision to darken Karthus's face more? I thought his rework already solved the skeleton problem?
What do you think about an Arcade Zac skin? Completely off-topic, I know, but I think it'd be cool. His body could have Arcade Hecarim neon rainbows flowing up and down it.
So the potential for a skeleton themed champion is still in the clear, so long as it isn't obviously human?
Plus Cho and Kog aren't "human skeletons" so they aren't effected.
Doubt that skins are ok,considering that the face of karthus was originally obscured in almost all of his skins as well.

That does leave the question of Grim Reaper Karthus still hanging, then. His face is partially obscured, but is still obviously bare bone, while his arms are most definitely lacking any semblance of flesh.

Is the theme of the skin so good at communicating that he is no longer or never was human that he can bypass the normal restrictions?
From what I know it is ok to depict the grim reaper as a skeleton,which is why grim reaper karthus wasn't censored.

In China, it says skeletons are 100% ok, so long as they do not promote "superstition." Death isn't a superstitious force. Skeletons animated through generic magics, also okay, but deliberate necromancy or for religious purposes are bad.

It has more to do with human skeletons,though some developers go the extra mile and take out inhuman skeletons as well.

It is appearantly also ok to depict the grim reaper as a skeleton,which is why the chinese grim reaper-karthus wasn't censored.
The Grim Reaper doesn't promote "superstition" as it is a blanket symbol for death. China is completely fine with skeletons, so long as they don't promote "superstition."
